metadata.title: Enhancing by nano-engineering: Hierarchical architectures as oxygen reduction/ evolution reactions for zinc-air batteries

sections.heading: Available online 31 July 2019
sections.text:
0378-7753/© 2019 Published by Elsevier B.V.
Enhancing by nano-engineering: Hierarchical architectures as oxygen reduction/ evolution reactions for zinc-air batteries
Tayyaba Najam 1, Syed Shoaib Ahmad Shah 1, Wei Ding **, Jianghai Deng, Zidong Wei *

sections.heading: Chongqing Key Laboratory of Chemical Process for Clean Energy and Resource Utilization, School of Chemistry and Chemical Engineering, Chongqing University,
sections.text:
Shazhengjie 174, Chongqing, 400044, China
H I G H L I G H T S G R A P H I C A L A B S T R A C T
� Nano-engineering of hierarchical architectures through controlled pyrolysis. � Highly modest and fast route for syn-
thesizing bifunctional electrocatalyst. � The superior activity ascribed to the
growth of carbon nanotubes on 2D nanosheets. � Better catalytic performance than high
cost precious electrocatalysts.
A R T I C L E I N F O

sections.heading: Keywords:
sections.text:
Nano-engineering Hierarchical architecture Electrocatalysis Zinc-air batteries
A B S T R A C T
Developing efficient electrocatalysts is extremely desirable to decrease the overall cost of electrochemical devices. It usually lies in interface modification for improving intrinsic activity of active sites, and structural optimization for facilitating mass transport. Herein, we rationally design a series of carbon-based hierarchical architectures as bifunctional electrocatalysts through control pyrolysis of metal organic frameworks coated layered double hydroxide nanoplatelets. Three kinds of catalysts with hierarchical structures are produced, nanoparticles dispersed on carbonized metal oxide nanosheets, carbon nanotubes vertically grown on carbonized metal oxide nanosheets, and carbon nanosheets vertically grown on carbonized metal oxide nanosheets. Among them, the carbon nanotubes vertically grown on carbonized metal oxide nanosheets electrocatalyst possesses the highest electrochemical surface area, lowest charge-transfer resistance, and the fast mass transfer rate, owing to its unique hierarchical porous structure. These properties lead to excellent catalytic activities for oxygen reduction/evolution reactions in terms of half-wave potential (835 mV) and low overpotential (280 mV), which make it a significant electrocatalyst for zinc-air batteries with respectable discharge-charge performance, peak power density (235 mW cm 2), specific capacitance (875 mAh g 1) and better stability than precious metal catalysts.
* Corresponding author. ** Corresponding author.
E-mail addresses: dingwei128@cqu.edu.cn (W. Ding), zdwei@cqu.edu.cn (Z. Wei). 1 Author Contribution: These authors contributed equally.
Contents lists available at ScienceDirect
Journal of Power Sources
journal homepage: www.elsevier.com/locate/jpowsour
https://doi.org/10.1016/j.jpowsour.2019.226919 Received 3 April 2019; Received in revised form 14 May 2019; Accepted 20 July 2019
Journal of Power Sources 438 (2019) 226919

sections.heading: 1. Introduction
sections.text:
Oxygen reduction/evolution reactions (ORR/OER) are considered as highly significant electrochemical reactions in energy-related devices [1–3]. Particularly, these pathways play a key role during the performance of metal-air batteries through efficient charge and discharge activity of oxygen electrodes. However, these reactions are considered to be notorious due to their intrinsic slow kinetics that hindered their large-scale practical applications [4–6]. At present, precious metal-based catalysts play key roles in these reactions. However, their scarceness and cost have hindered the practical utilization of renewable energy devices [7,8]. Recently, numerous non-precious metal catalysts (NPMCs) have been developed for these notorious electrochemical reactions to effectively boost reaction kinetics, thus approaching or surpassing PGM catalysts [9,10]. Careful selection of nitrogen-containing ligands and transition metal atoms result in greater number of active sites which reduces the energy consumption via accelerated electrochemical reactions [11–18]. Hierarchical metal-carbon architectures, a combination of heteroatom-doped carbon heterostructures and transition metals in the form of carbides, oxides, or nitrides, have drawn special attention due to their tunable nanostructures with appropriate mesoporous distribution and high surface area [19–22]. For large scale application, their catalytic activities need to be further improved as
compared with the state of art precious metal catalysts. The key issues for performance enhancement of hierarchical metal-carbon architectures lie in surface/interface modification for improving intrinsic activity of active sites, and meso/micro/nano structural optimization for facilitating mass transport and utilization of active sites [23–26]. The electrocatalytic active sites are usually formed by the coordination of metal-nitrogen-carbon (Me–N–C) species (Me ¼ Fe, Co, Mn, Ni, etc.) [27–30]. The electronic and chemical interactions between metal species and the surrounding atoms are considered as the key factors of intrinsic activity [31–35]. For example, the ORR activity of metal oxides can be greatly enhanced by interacting with nitrogen atoms as compared with carbon atoms [36–39]. The incorporation of metal atoms gives M-Nx active sites, which produce the activation effects on the nearby carbon and nitrogen atoms, which tend to lower the energy barrier and enhance the catalytic activity [40]. The higher intrinsic catalytic active sites formed during pyrolysis due to the strong interaction among metal atom and nitrogen species. It is also evidenced by X-ray absorption techniques or M€ossbauer spectroscopy that the speculated ORR active sites are associated with N-coordinated metal MNx (x ¼ 2 to 4) [41–43]. The surface atomic arrangements of metal species also show great influence on catalytic properties. Our previous report also showed that an inverse spinel structure exhibits a dissimilarity effect in accelerating the cleavage and activation of O–O bonds when the octahedral sites of spinel
Scheme. 1. Schematic illustration for the synthesis of Co-CNTs/NS-CoOxAlOy, Co-NPs/NS-CoOxAlOy and Co-NS/NS-AlOy; In the controlled pyrolysis, the temperature was firtly increased to 435 �C/or 120 �C with holding time of 1 h for pre-growth of carbon materials or for dehydration, and further increased to 900 �C with holding time of 2 h.
T. Najam et al.
Journal of Power Sources 438 (2019) 226919
are occupied by two different metal atoms [44]. For another side, the combination with carbon conductor is usually needed for metal oxides catalyst to improve the electronic conductivity. This leads to a relatively complex meso/micro/nano catalyst structure, which may increase the resistance of mass transport and hidden active sites [45,46]. It is very challenging but necessary to control the metal species position where active sites are accessible to reactants and facile to release the products. Therefore, constructing hierarchical nanostructured materials with desirable electrocatalytic activity and porosity has been the subject of many researches.
Herein, we rationally fabricated a series of carbon-based hierarchical architecture as multifunctional electrocatalysts through nanoengineering with precisely controlled nanostructure and metal species locations. The nano-engineering involves two steps: i) surficial induced growth of metal organic frameworks (MOFs) on layered double hydroxide (LDH) nanoplatelets (MOFs-LDH), and ii) controlled pyrolysis of MOFs-LDH. The as-prepared MOFs-LDH nanocomposites can serve as generic precursors to form various M-N/NC- supported ultrafine metal
and metal oxide hierarchical nanostructures. As shown in Scheme 1, the LDH transformed into carbon film coated metal oxides nanosheet, and the ZIF-67 (Co-based zeolitic imidazole framework) was then nanoengineered to be metallic nanoparticle (NP), carbon nanotubes (CNT) and carbon nanosheets (NS) on the basis of controlled decomposition of precursors in the pyrolysis.
Three kinds of hierarchical structures are constructed, including metallic Co NPs embedded in NS-CoOxAlOy, Co-CNTs (Co NPs packaged at the tip of CNTs) vertically grown on NS-CoOxAlOy, and Co-NS (Co NPs loaded on the surface of NS) vertically grown on NS-AlOy. Specifically, hierarchical nanostructures are accompanied by the distortion of the surface structure and inherent large specific surface, which is conducive to the fast electron transportation and creates more active sites to improve the electrocatalytic efficiency. Among the synthesized electrocatalysts, the Co-CNTs/NS-CoOxAlOy, Co-CNTs vertically grown on 2D surface of NS-CoOxAlOy, possesses the highest electrochemical surface area, lowest charge-transfer resistance, and the fast mass transfer rate, owing to its combination of nanotube and nanosheet assembly.
T. Najam et al.
Journal of Power Sources 438 (2019) 226919

sections.heading: 2. Result and discussion
sections.text:
The X-ray diffraction (XRD) was firstly used to monitor the synthesis of these electrocatalysts. The growth of ZIF-67 on both of ZnAl-LDH and CoAl-LDH nanosheets were carried out via a similar method for comparison. The XRD patterns of ZIF-67/CoAl-LDH and ZIF-67/ZnAl-LDH, as shown in Fig. 1a, present the superimposition of ZIF-67 and LDH phases, thus specifying the effective coordination of ZIF-67 with LDH. The new series of peaks are appeared at ⁓26⁰, 44⁰, and 51⁰ after pyrolysis which correspond to the (002) diffraction peak of graphitic carbon, (111) and (200) crystal planes of face-centered-cubic (fcc) Co phase, respectively (Fig. 1b).
The scanning electron microscopy (SEM) image shows thin hexagonal platelets morphology with a diameter of 1–2 μm for the as-prepared CoAl-LDH (Fig. 2a). Based on the interaction between metal sites of LDH surface and 2-methylimidazole, ZIF-67 particles were surficial-induced grow on the surface of LDH. As shown in Fig. 2c, numerous rhombic ZIF-67 polyhedrons are homogeneously immobilized on both sides of CoAl-LDH nanosheets to form a sandwiched structure with ZIF-67 suspended surface. After heating first at 435 �C, then at 900 �C for 2 h under nitrogen environment, the morphology of as prepared ZIF-67/CoAl-LDH transformed into worm-like Co-CNT assembled on surface of 2D NSCoOxAlOy (Fig. 2d) [47]. While programmed heating first at 120 �C then 900 �C, stimulates the growth of Co NPs embedded on the surface of ZIF-67/CoAl-LDH (Fig. 2e). The ZIF-67 embedded on ZnAl-LDH precursor (ZIF-67/ZnAl-LDH) transformed into small nanosheets on 2D assembly of NS-AlOy (Fig. 2f-f1). TEM (transmission electron microscopy) images further confirm the existence of ~11 nm Co-CNT assembly with a hollow and top opening morphology for Co-CNTs/NS-CoOxAlOy (Fig. 3c and d), and certain amount of cobalt nanoparticles are also observed in the bottom of CNTs, which serve as catalyst for the growth and illustration of Co-CNTs. It is noted that the abundant edges rather than basal plane exposed on the surface of Co-CNTs because the graphitic layers in the Co-CNT walls are not perfectly analogous to the axis direction with a basal plane of Co-CNTs (Fig. 3d). Furthermore, STEM-EDS (energy dispersive spectroscopy) elemental mapping shows the homogeneous distribution of Co-species on the surface of Co-CNTs/NS-CoOxAlOy (Fig. 3e and figure S2).
The pre-treatments, where the dehydration of LDH interlayer water and seeds formation occurs, are responsible for the different nanostructure formation. The Co NPs seeds formed during the carbonization of ZIF-67/CoAl-LDH at 435 �C for 1 h, facilitate the formation of carbon nanotubes on the 2D assembly [47] without providing any so-called H2
atmosphere [48,49], while the released interlayer water during the heating at relatively low temperature (holding at 120 �C or direct heating to 900 �C) destroyed the carbon precursors for producing carbon nanotubes. Interestingly, the sample when carbonized first at temperatures 120 �C and then raised to 900 �C displays reduced catalytic performance for nanotube formation. Despite they still contained almost similar type of carbon, more Co NPs are produced because reduction of Co becomes faster after the evaporation of interlayer water at 120 �C. This phenomenon is further evidenced by thermogravimetric analysis (TGA), which shows that the hydro framework (interlayer water molecules) in Co–Al LDH and Zn–Al LDH initially starts to collapse with a continuous weight loss until ~ 435 �C (Figure. SEM images shows that only Co nanoparticles (ZIF-67/CoAl-LDH) catalyzed the construction of graphitic carbon nanotubes from the organic framework of ZIF-67. It is clear that ZIF-67 framework starts to collapse at ~435 �C with continuous weight loss until ~600 �C (Fig. S2d). Furthermore, Fig. S3a1 shows that the growth of ZIF-67 at Co–Al LDH prevents the rapid loss of interlayer water and there is no significant weight loss at initial temperature range (50–150 �C). This is further confirmed by heating Co–Al LDH and ZIF-67/CoAl-LDH at 120 �C for 1 h (Fig. S3b-b1), ~9.5% weight loss is observed for Co–Al LDH while ZIF-67/CoAl-LDH has no significant weight loss (~2.5%). With programmed heating process (120 �C for 1 h), the interlayer water molecules rapidly removed at low temperature which tends to affect the nanostructures morphology. While, the initial heating at 435 �C produced the Co nanoparticles which in-situ catalyzed the formation of carbon nanotubes.
The textural properties of the electrocatalysts were investigated by N2 adsorption-desorption measurements (Fig. S4). The identified type IV isotherm with rapid uptake at high relative pressure shows a mesoporous structure incorporated in the Co-CNTs/NS-CoOxAlOy. The BET surface area of Co-CNTs/NS-CoOxAlOy is detected to be 131.53 m2 g 1, notably higher than Co-NPs/NS-CoOxAlOy (82.01 m2 g 1), NS-CoOxAlOy/C (78.56 m2 g 1) and Co-CNTs (106.94 m2 g 1), but smaller than that of Co-NS/NS-AlOy (179.98 m2 g 1). The high surface area of Co-NS/ NS-AlOy is attributed to the evaporation of Zn in ZnAl-LDH which leads to the formation of numbers of microspores. The pore diameter fell in the range from 2.0 to 10 nm for Co-CNTs/NS-CoOxAlOy (inset; Fig. S4a). It is large enough to transport/diffusion of small molecules like O2 (a kinetic diameter of 0.346 nm). The BET surface area of Co-CNTs/NSCoOxAlOy further increased to 448.25 m2 g 1 after typical acid washing with removal of metal nanoparticles (Fig. S4e).
The XPS survey spectra (Fig. 4a) exposed that the Co-CNTs/NSCoOxAlOy, Co-NPs/NS-CoOxAlOy and Co-NS/NS-AlOy comprise of
T. Najam et al.
Journal of Power Sources 438 (2019) 226919
elemental contents as; C, N, O, Co and Al. The N1s spectra of Co-CNTs/ NS-CoOxAlOy as shown in Fig. 4b, exhibits three major peaks characterized as oxidized-N (404 eV), graphitic-N (401.1 eV), and pyridinic-N (398.4 eV) [50,51]. While, the Pyrrolic-N peak is appeared at 399.9 eV in case of Co-NPs/NS-CoOxAlOy and Co-NS/NS-AlOy. Furthermore, an additional peak observed in Co-CNTs/NS-CoOxAlOy at 399.2 eV which is assigned to CoN4 peak (nitrogen bonded to cobalt), an active center for some electrochemical reactions along with pyridinic-N and graphitic-N. This CoN4 peak shifted towards higher binding energy site as compare to Co-NPs/NS-CoOxAlOy ( 0.1 eV) and Co-NS/NS-AlOy ( 0.3 eV) samples, which might be responsible for creating stabilizing effect against Co NPs oxidation/dissolution. The high resolution Co2p spectra of Co-CNTs/NS-CoOxAlOy displays three forms of Co species, Co–Nx (782 eV), CoOx or CoCxNy (780.5 eV), and metallic Co (778.5 eV), respectively (Fig. 4c), indicating a multi-functioned active material formation with three kind of active sites in our method. Furthermore, the C1s spectra described three types of peaks as C–C, C–O–C and O–C–O peaks (Fig. S6a). Similar behavior of positive shift in binding energy is observed by Co-CNTs/NS-CoOxAlOy.
We have studied the electrocatalytic activity of Co-CNTs/NS-CoOxAlOy, NS/NS-AlOy and NPs/NS-CoOxAlOy in three electrode assembly for ORR and OER (Fig. 5). Among the as-prepared catalysts (Fig. 5a and b), the Co-CNTs/NS-CoOxAlOy demonstrated the best ORR performance in terms of Eonset/E1/2 (0.94 V/0.835 V) with less H2O2 production (2%), which is comparable to the state-of-the-art Pt/C catalyst (0.98 V/ 0.861V). While, the overpotential required for OER (current density of 10 mA cm 2 denoted as η j ¼ 10) is 280 mV for Co-CNTs/NS-CoOxAlOy, which is much lower than those of other reference samples and the commercial IrO2 (Fig. 5d and e). The results show that CNTs with Co-Nx sites growing on 2D assembly i.e., Co-CNTs/NS-CoOxAlOy, have more catalytic activity as compared to NS with Co loaded growing on 2D assembly, i.e., Co-NS/NS-AlOy. When abundant Co NPs embedded 2D assembly, as in case of Co-NP/NS-CoOxAlOy, the activity was further reduced. The enhanced catalytic performances were further confirmed by lower tafel slope. Fig. S8b shows that the Co-CNTs/NS-CoOxAlOy having tafel slope of 83 mV dec 1 nearby to the commercial Pt/C (74 mV dec 1) for ORR, and is much less than that of other hierarchical nanostructured catalyst, including Co-NS/NS-AlOy (101 mV dec 1), Co-NPs/
T. Najam et al.
Journal of Power Sources 438 (2019) 226919
NS-CoOxAlOy (144 mV dec 1), Co-CNTs (107 mV dec 1), and NSCoOxAlOy/C (134 mV dec 1). For OER performance as shown in Figs. S9a and a similar order of tafel slope was also observed, that is, CoCNTs/NS-CoOxAlOy < Co-NS/NS-AlOy < Co-NPs/NS-CoOxAlOy (Table 1). The electrochemical double layer capacitance (Cdl), calculated for OER (Fig. S9b), shows that Co-CNTs/NS-CoOxAlOy exhibited the highest surface roughness and largest number of exposed active sites with Cdl value of 74.95 and 31.17 μF cm 2 for OER. The Cdl values of CoCNTs/NS-CoOxAlOy are higher than Co-NS/NS-AlOy, Co-NPs/NS-CoOxAlOy, Co-CNTs and NS-CoOxAlOy/C. These results indicate that CNTs vertically grown on hierarchical nanostructure facilitates the catalytic active site formation and exposure. The electrochemical impedance spectroscopy measurements further reveals that CNTs vertically grown on hierarchical nanostructure enhances the mass diffusion and electron transfer during the catalysis. As shown in Fig. S8c and Fig. S9c, the calculated charge-transfer resistance (Rct) value of Co-CNTs/NS-CoOxAlOy for ORR (125 Ω) and OER (15 Ω), are the lowest among other assynthesized catalysts, implying more favorable charge transport kinetics on Co-CNTs/NS-CoOxAlOy [52]. This is attributed to the CNTs vertically grown mesoporous structure, high proportion of graphitic-N and pyridinic-N [53,54], combined effects promoted by Co, N doping [55,56], efficient mass transport for oxygen and electrolyte enabled by the interconnected nanotube framework, possibly promotes the intrinsic activity of Co-CNTs/NS-CoOxAlOy [57–59].
Furthermore, the Co-CNTs/NS-CoOxAlOy also possesses a superb stability after constant 10000 cycling for ORR, E1/2 slightly shift (ca. 10 mV) while drastic loss in catalytic activity of Pt/C (20%) with an E1/2 negative shift of >25 mV under the same conditions (Fig. 5c). The CoCNTs/NS-CoOxAlOy shows highest electron transfer numbered of 3.94–3.99 with respect to Pt/C and other as-synthesized electrocatalysts (Fig. S8a). The durability tests for OER (Fig. 5f) show the operating overpotential after 30 h with 8% activity degradation for Co-CNTs/NSCoOxAlOy while IrO2 catalyst severely lost its catalytic activity with 35% activity degradation. These results indicate that the constructed hierarchical architectures may alleviate the detachment of active species
during the long-term operation leading to a relatively better stability. Previous studies indicated that metal nanoparticles embedded in
carbon framework can effectively catalyzed electrocatalytic ORRpathway [60,61]. Inorder to investigate the active sites in carbon-framework, the metallic cobalt species in Co-CNTs/NS-CoOxAlOy is removed by acid washing in 0.5 M H2SO4 solution (denoted as Co-CNTs/NS-CoOxAlOy (A.W)) [61]. Most of the Co NPs which play crucial part for enhancing catalytic performance, are successfully leached out as confirmed by XRD results (Fig. S5). The ORR performance of Co-CNTs/NS-CoOxAlOy (A.W) decreases with difference of Eonset/E1/2 (60 mV/25 mV) and current density reduces to 10% at 0.6 V (vs RHE) as compared to Co-CNTs/NS-CoOxAlOy (Fig. S11a). A great loss in OER catalytic performance was also observed as compared to Co-CNTs/NS-CoOxAlOy (Fig. S11b). The above results confirmed the beneficial contribution Co NPs for ORR and OER pathways, which could be attributed to the surrounding graphitic shell with improved electronic configuration.
Usually, one catalyst is only suitable for only one reaction [62], because the requirements for catalysis are considered to be complicated due to multi-step proton coupled electron transfer, low efficiency, and comparatively high overpotential [6]. The Co-CNTs/NS-CoOxAlOy in our work, however, shows best performance as bifunctional electrocatalyst for ORR and OER. The synergistic catalytic effects between carbon coated Co NPs and the N-dopants (MOFs) can be anticipated for superior performance of Co-CNTs/NS-CoOxAlOy as a bifunctional catalyst: 1) Nitrogen atoms are inherently better in interacting with reactants (i.e., protons/water) than carbon atoms due to the presence of lone-pair electrons on the former. Therefore, the existence of N-dopants favors the interaction and thus performance [39,63,64]. 2) The facile electron transfer results due to reduced local work function because of the existence of metal NPs [1,11,22,56,65]. 3) Synergetic coupling of Co–N4 moieties with metallic Co cores surrounded by semiconductive Co3O4 shell, probably estimated to deliver excellent multifunctional catalytic performance [14]. In addition, minor charge-transfer resistance, greater electrochemical surface area,
T. Najam et al.
Journal of Power Sources 438 (2019) 226919
structural defects, and the distinctive hierarchical architecture of Co-CNTs on 2D assembly (with wide pore-size distribution) could undoubtedly boost the mass transport of ionic species as well as reaction kinetics for good electrocatalytic property of Co-CNTs/NS-CoOxAlOy [3, 33,66,67]. The inevitable mild oxidation of surficial cobalt species, considered as favorable for electrocatalytic performance whereby Co2þ plays a key role towards ORR while Co3þ is regarded as active for OER [14,50,68].
A rechargeable zinc-air battery assembled with a zinc plate (anode) and Co-CNTs/NS-CoOxAlOy (cathode) shows much better performance than the commercial Pt/C and IrO2 (cathode) as shown in Fig. 6. The peak power density for the Zn-air battery constructed from the CoCNTs/NS-CoOxAlOy electrode are 235 mW cm 2, which is 65 mW cm 2 higher than that of Zn-air battery constructed from electrode (Pt/C þ IrO2). Furthermore, when charge and discharge current densities are applied, the Co-CNTs/NS-CoOxAlOy electrode exhibits superior performance as compare to the Pt/C and IrO2 (Fig. 6b), which comes from its outstanding ORR/OER-pathways. The galvanostatic charge and discharge cycling measurements shows excellent stability of Co-CNTs/ NS-CoOxAlOy than Pt/C and IrO2 air-electrode at 20 mA cm 2 (Fig. 6c). Throughout the cycling test for more than 10 h, charge-discharge voltage gap of only 20 mV is observed by Co-CNTs/NS-CoOxAlOy, while Pt/C and IrO2 electrode shows dramatic stability loss. Fig. 6d shows the comparative analysis for voltage gap at various discharge current densities to investigate the basis of utmost catalytic performance of Co-CNTs/NS-CoOxAlOy. Notably, the voltage gap increased from 20.7 mV, and 30.2 mV–51 mV with increasing current densities from 10 mA cm 2 to 20 mA cm 2 to 30 mA cm 2. Thus, confirming the robust conductive property of Co-CNTs/NS-CoOxAlOy at higher current densities. The open-circuit voltage of 1.51 V, 940 Wh kg 1 of energy density (10 mA cm 2) and specific capacity of 875 mAh g 1 (10 mA cm 2) with Co-CNTs/NS-CoOxAlOy electrode is attained, which is far better than air electrode of Pt/C þ IrO2 (595 mAh g 1) (Figs. S12a–c). These results show the excellent performance of the Co-CNTs/NS-CoOxAlOy for rechargeable Zn-air battery.

sections.heading: 3. Conclusion
sections.text: We have reported the nano-engineering of MOFs-LDH nanocomposites via controlled pyrolysis and surficial induced methods to architecture hierarchical nanostructures with various morphologies including Co-NS, Co-NPs and Co-CNTs growth on 2D assembly. The resulting Co-CNTs/NS-CoOxAlOy electrocatalyst, the vertically grown Co-CNTs on 2D surface of NS-CoOxAlOy, accompanied by the distortion of the surface structure with bifunctional active species formation leads to excellent performance nearly close to Pt/C (20%) for ORR-pathway with only ΔE1/2 of 26 mV, and exhibiting low OER-overpotential of 280 mV which is superior than IrO2 (340 mV) at 10 mA cm 2 of current density. Furthermore, a respectable performance for zinc-air batteries is observed which is comparatively high than Pt-based and IrO2 electrocatalysts. Thus, the synergistic catalytic effects between carbon coated Co NPs and the N-dopants can be attributed to the promising bifunctional performance. Moreover, its excellent stability than Pt-based and IrO2 electrocatalysts would guarantee its practical utilization for stable energy storage devices.
